No change in policy.    Additional information in this press release when the mandatory mask order was introduced in Paris, which is still the latest status on the Parisian local government's website:  https://archive.vn/3zD5b

In accordance with decree n ° 2020-884 of July 17, 2020, the wearing of a mask has become compulsory in closed places welcoming the public.    In addition, decree n ° 2020-944 of July 30, 2020 provides for the possibility for the prefects, when the local epidemic situation requires it, to extend the obligation to wear a mask to all relevant places , that is to say - also say public space.  This is an essential protection measure, especially in closed environments or when there is a high population density (market, busy street, etc.). In addition to barrier gestures (hand washing, physical distancing), it is the mask that filters the droplets from sneezing, coughing, or even prolonged discussion.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19
No policy change

No availability yet but plans in place to start vaccination in January. Vaccination will be rolled out in three phases:    Phase 1: January 2021 – elderly care home residents, and residence staff who are at risk of developing severe illness (about one million people)  Phase 2: February 2021 -  people who are at risk of developing severe illness, and health care workers – about 14 million people.  Phase 3: spring 2021 – availability for the entire population, although still prioritized e.g. by age.  Vaccination will be free and voluntary.    https://archive.vn/aLCoS

14. December 2020, The Government with new measures for Christmas    Retailers at Christmas: Businesses should ensure that hand sanitiser is readily available and that stores are kept clean. Signs should be clearly displayed to help customers keep to the recommendations. Staff should use protective gear where necessary. Retailers can help by making face masks available for customers. If retailers cannot limit the number of customers so that the recommended distances can be maintained, then both customers and staff are advised to wear face masks.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201214155432/https://corona.fo/news/748/the-government-with-new-measures-for-christmas?_l=en

14. December 2020, The Government with new measures for Christmas    · Sport: All indoor sporting events should be held without spectators. This applies to both adult and children’s competitions. Coaches and assistants can be present during matches.    · Schools and daycare centres are advised not to hold larger events to which people from outside the institution are usually invited. This includes Christmas celebrations which would normally be attended by parents and other family members. Christmas church services for school pupils and preschool children should not be organised as usual this year      https://web.archive.org/web/20201214155432/https://corona.fo/news/748/the-government-with-new-measures-for-christmas?_l=en

14. December 2020, The Government with new measures for Christmas    · Schools and daycare centres are advised not to hold larger events to which people from outside the institution are usually invited. This includes Christmas celebrations which would normally be attended by parents and other family members. Christmas church services for school pupils and preschool children should not be organised as usual this year.    · Christmas shopping: Special emphasis should be placed on social distancing hand and hygiene and. It is advisable that only one person in the household does the shopping, rather than going several together. It is also advisable to go shopping when there are fewer people.  Face masks are recommended when a lot of people are in a shop. If you have come to the Faroe Islands from abroad, you should not go shopping at all until you have received a negative result from the test that you should take 6 days after arrival.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201214155432/https://corona.fo/news/748/the-government-with-new-measures-for-christmas?_l=en

3rd Dec 2020, Mandatory border testing continues until 31 March. This strategy has played an important role in limiting the spread of the virus; however, the commission is keen to point out that testing travellers are only part of the solution.    Social distancing, good hygiene, staying at home if any symptoms appear and taking a follow-up test on day six after arriving from abroad remain crucial in the fight against Covid-19, says the epidemic commission.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208143045/https://corona.fo/news/734/mandatory-border-testing-continues-until-31-march?_l=en

11. December 2020, Test center opening hours are scheduled. Testing is free of charge.     Those wishing to be tested in Klaksvík, Tórshavn and Tvøroyri are required to pre-register here or book a time slot on 304545. Telephone opening hours are Monday to Friday 14pm to 16pm.  Once registered, people receive a notification by phone and email, which they are asked to show on arrival.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201215105712/https://corona.fo/news/675/test-center-opening-hours?_l=en

Face masks must be worn in all enclosed public spaces, including taxis and public transportation. Violators of face musk rules are subject to a 20 GEL (about 6 USD) fine. There are some exceptions for children under 6, people with disabilities, or who have health problems that prevent them from wearing a face covering. Vaccines are not yet being administered, but there is a government-funded policy in place:    Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis met with advisors and government ministers virtually on Saturday 5 December 20202 in order to discuss the country’s Covid-19 vaccination plan.    Reportedly, vaccinations will begin in January, with healthcare workers having priority. Greeks will be able to make appointments to receive the free shot at one of the country’s 1,018 vaccination centers that are currently being created in order to best distribute the vaccine to as many people as possible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201209210724/https://greece.greekreporter.com/2020/12/05/greece-to-begin-covid-19-vaccinations-in-january-1383-new-cases-saturday/

Travelers whose test is older than 48 hours will be allowed to enter Croatia, but they will be issued a self-isolation order and will have to be tested again locally, at their own expense. Having an expired PCR test upon arrival will allow for a shortened period of time in self-isolation pending a negative result of a local PCR test. Those who do not provide a negative PCR test upon arrival will be ordered to quarantine/self-isolate for at least 7 days prior to taking a local PCR test.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201122103504/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

From 01-Dec-20 until 15-Jan-21 there will be stricter controls on people crossing the border into Croatia. On December 19, economic protections are extended until 01 July.  According to this, the moratorium on loan repayments for families and businesses will be extended unchanged for six months until 1 July. The moratorium will be automatically extended, only those who want to repay their loan despite the moratorium will have to visit their bank, the Prime Minister said.  It also announced that businesses forced to close temporarily as a a cause of disease measures would be supported by the government in December and January by waived and taking over two-thirds of wage costs. In addition to catering, hotels and tourism, the remission of contributions and wage subsidies will be extended to private bus companies that are forced to take a break.  Viktor Orban also said that business taxes for small and medium-sized enterprises and sole proprietors will be cut by half from 1 January. These businesses account for the most jobs and are the most vulnerable during the epidemic, he justified the measure, adding that municipalities of less than 25,000 inhabitants will receive support from the government and the financial situation of larger municipalities will be reviewed individually.  The fourth decision is to help families with children and children with a reduced home improvement loan of up to HUF 6 million with a maximum interest rate of 3 percent. Of this, HUF 3 million is a non-refundable grant, which can be used at the end of the renovation and automatically reduces the amount of the loan, the Prime Minister explained.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219210422/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/orban-viktor-kormany-gazdasagvedelmi-akcioterv-kiegesziteserol-rendelkezett

On 18 December, it was announced that vaccinations against the coronavirus can begin on 27 or 28 December, in the first round a sufficient amount will arrive in Hungary for 35,000 people, and health workers will be vaccinated in the first place, Prime Minister Viktor Orban announced on Kossuth radio's Good Morning, Hungary! on his show. Vaccination will be voluntary and free of charge.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219205730/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/orban-december-27-28-kezdodhetnek-az-elso-oltasok

"In line with current NPHET advice in respect of Level 5, schools, early learning and childcare services will continue to remain open and are deemed essential.   Higher and adult education: Primarily online with exemptions for essential onsite activities."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123142554/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/2dc71-level-5/#schools-and-creches

No change. Early learning is open but higher levels are closed except for essential onsite activities.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201201204457/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/2dc71-level-5/#schools-and-creches

Most workplaces closed as Ireland moves to Level 5 restrictions on 21 October for 6 weeks.    Professional, elite sports and inter-county Gaelic games, horse-racing and greyhound racing are permitted to continue behind closed doors. Only essential workers can travel to work and only essential retail and essential services can remain open. Construction and manufacturing can stay in operation.     Coded as a 3 as most non-essential businesses are closed.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123142554/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/2dc71-level-5/#retail-and-services-for-example-hairdressers-beauticians-barbers

No change. All businesses except essential are closed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201201204457/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/2dc71-level-5/#retail-and-services-for-example-hairdressers-beauticians-barbers

From 4th December in Ireland restaurants and pubs operating as restaurants (serving a substantial meal) can open for indoor dining with additional restrictions, with a maximum of 6 people per table. All retail shops and shopping centres can open. All services such as hairdressers, beauticians, barbers and opticians can open with strict adherence to sectoral guidance on protective measures.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214192520/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/ad569-level-3/
Organized events (indoor and outdoor) are banned.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201201204457/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/2dc71-level-5/

Organised events can take place in Ireland as long as these are controlled environments with a named event organiser, owner or manager.  Gatherings of up to 15 people can take place. Face coverings are recommended in busy or crowded areas.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201214192520/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/ad569-level-3/

"At Level 5, the public health risk means that you will be asked to stay at home, with certain exceptions. There will be no gatherings other than small numbers at funerals and weddings."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123142554/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/2dc71-level-5/

Gatherings are not permitted except for small outdoor gatherings (involving two households but no number given)  https://web.archive.org/web/20201201204457/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/2dc71-level-5/

People are advised to walk or cycle where possible. Public transport will operate at 25% capacity for the purposes of allowing those providing essential services to get to work. "Stay at home.    Exercise within 5 kilometres of home.    There will be a penalty for movement outside 5 kilometres of home, with the following exceptions: travel to and from work, where work involves providing an essential service, to attend medical appointments and collect medicines and other health products, travel to attend disability day services, travel to attend a court, for food shopping, to take school aged children to permitted training as provided for in the Exercise and Sporting section above, for vital family reasons, such as providing care to children, elderly or vulnerable people, and in particular for those who live alone but excluding social family visits, for farming purposes, that is food production or care of animals, to attend a wedding or funeral and to visit a grave"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123142554/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/2dc71-level-5/
Residents are asked to stay home except for essential activities under the Level 5 restrictions.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201201204457/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/2dc71-level-5/

"Stay at home.    Exercise within 5 kilometres of home. Recommended to stay in your county apart from work, education, medical and other essential purposes, if appropriate.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214192520/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/ad569-level-3/

"On November 9, Ireland implemented the EU-wide “traffic light” system to regularize travel within the EU/international travel between member states. The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control publishes a weekly map that assigns countries a red, orange, grey (denoting no information), or green rating based on an agreed set of criteria including COVID-19 infection rates.  International arrivals from red, orange, grey, and non-EU countries (with limited exceptions) are advised to self-isolate for 14 days. In line with the EU traffic light approach, travellers from green regions, or those arriving from Northern Ireland, are not asked to restrict their movements. Currently, all passengers entering Ireland from orange, red, and grey regions are requested to restrict their movements for 14 days."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123141724/https://ie.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Arrivals are asked to self-quarantine for 14 days upon arrival (in line with EU-wide traffic light system). No ban on arrivals.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201206024447/https://ie.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Restrictions have been updated although coding remains the same.  Performing arts, cinema theatres and other cultural events may have up to 30 persons on stage, i.e. during rehearsals and shows. Up to 50 seated guests may be accommodated. Such guests must wear face masks. In addition, 100 children born in 2005 or later may be accommodated. Seats are to be numbered and labelled with the name of the guest. Neither breaks nor alcohol sales are permitted.  Restaurants may be open until 22:00 on all days but must comply with the 15-person limit rule and the 2-metre proximity limit between unrelated persons. Take-away meals may be served after 22:00.  Pharmacies, grocery stores and other stores may accept 5 persons for each 10 m2 of space and may have up to 100 customers in their premises, as long as it is possible to ensure at least 2 metres between persons who are unrelated.    Swimming pools are open and may accept up to 50% of their maximum number of guests according to their operating permit.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201213162115/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/what-is-ban-on-public-events

It should be noted that primary school students and students from remote places are allowed to attend schools in Kazakhstan from September 1. Whereas high schools and universities/colleges are still studying online. Currently, some regions are practicing a school closure for primary school students due to increased COVID-19 at the local level.  Link: https://archive.vn/PWUNI

On 4 December, Aksu city closed all levels of school. On December 7, Pavlodar and Ekibastuz cities will close all levels of school until 31 December. It should be mentioned that primary special classes (small group classes) are open across Kazakhstan. However, Aksu, Ekibastuz, and Pavlodar closed all primary classes. As a result, all education institutions are closed there.  Links: https://archive.vn/CG4aK https://archive.vn/VDdDX

By and large, countrywide quarantine restrictions have been relaxed.  Businesses that were previously closed – including gyms and fitness centers, pools, beaches, cultural facilities, museums, exhibits, entertainment centers, religious facilities, some movie theaters, food courts, and recreational facilities – have reopened, at least on weekdays, and may be subject to capacity limitations. Update on 2nd of December:    "Government approves tighter lockdown rules.    The adverse epidemic coronavirus (COVID-19) situation in Lithuania has necessitated further tightening of the lockdown rules by restricting the size of gatherings, banning the operation of temporary vendors in malls and supermarkets. It has also been recommended to discontinue short-term sales promotion measures to bring down visitor flows.    The Government has agreed to ban the operation of temporary vendors in shops, supermarkets and points of service, where sales are not made in physically separated premises but in common areas and passageways of malls and supermarkets. Exceptions apply to selling foodstuffs, pyrotechnic items and also to fixed vending stalls."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201210091436/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/government-approves-tighter-lockdown-rules

Currently, the contact tracing system in Lithuania is overwhelmed. On 3rd December, newly elected Prime Minister Ingrida Simonyte told that NVSC failed to do contact tracing for all positve cases. Moreover, the newly elected Minister of Health Arunas Dulkys on 12th December told that the priority at the time was that NVSC could complete contact tracing for all cases within 48 hours after positive test result, indicating that it is not currently done. Coded as 3 because testing is available to much of the asymptomatic population, but asymptomatic people only have access to a free PCR test if they receive an invitation from the government. Private laboratories also offer testing, but this is not free.     The Luxembourg government is embarking on a new phase of screening with the aim to test representative samples of the population in order to monitor developments and to be as flexible as possible in the event of an increase in the number of cases. This is the best way to break infection chains and effectively trace the contacts of infected people.    The COVID-19 test at the invitation of the Luxembourg Government concerns residents and cross-border workers. It is free of charge.    The Large Scale Testing strategy divides people into representative groups, e.g. according to business sector, age and place of residence. This means that members of the same household, residents of a residential area or a circle of colleagues receive invitations deliberately staggered by several weeks according to the targeted samples. This also makes it possible to maintain continuous testing. It is therefore a strategy based on a large scale sampling approach. This organised exercise makes it possible to control and keep the rate of infections at a very low level and thus ensure the protection of everyone. The test becomes a gesture of solidarity, and protects us all.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201130213106/https://covid19.public.lu/en/testing.html
No policy change.
No policy change.

In view of the alarming growth in the number of new COVID-19 infections, the Contact Tracing Unit of the Health Inspection Department has adapted its operating procedures in order to increase its responsiveness with respect to making contact.     People who have tested positive for COVID-19 should immediately go into self-isolation, without waiting for a call from the Contact Tracing Unit.    Any person who has tested positive for COVID-19 is contacted as soon as possible by the Health Inspection; and  is assigned a reference number. While waiting for a call from the Contact Tracing Unit, the person who has tested positive can help trace and identify people with whom they have had high-risk contact.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201130213748/https://guichet.public.lu/en/citoyens/sante-social/coronavirus/tracage-contact/participation-tracage-contacts.html

On 1 December 2020, the Cabinet of Ministers extended the emergency situation introducing stricter safety measures and restriction until January 11, 2021.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201207030317/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/emergency-situation-has-been-extended-until-11-january-introducing-stricter-safety    The on-site study process shall take place only in kindergartens and from grade 1 to grade 4. An area of at least 3 square meters per pupil must be provided. From 3 December, kindergarten employees shall wear masks at all times. From 4 January, both pupils and teachers shall wear masks during lessons and outside the learning process at schools.  The completion of higher education, adult continuous vocational training, vocational in-service training, and non-formal education programs shall be held only remotely. On the other hand, practical skills that cannot be acquired remotely can be acquired in person only individually - one teacher with one student.  The practical parts of interest education can take place in person only individually. Practices of choirs and wind instruments are not allowed in person.
No change to previous policy (running until 11th January)

On 1 December 2020, the Cabinet of Ministers extended the emergency situation introducing stricter safety measures and restriction until January 11, 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201207030317/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/emergency-situation-has-been-extended-until-11-january-introducing-stricter-safety  rom 3 December, 15 square meters per visitor must be provided in shops and service points. Information on the number of people allowed must be clearly visible at the entrance. Economic service providers, shops and event organizers must ensure that people who do not wear a face mask or do it incorrectly are not allowed on the premises and services are not provided to those who do not comply with epidemiological safety requirements.  All shops and the shopping centers, regardless of the total sales area, shall be open on weekdays as usual. However, only pharmacies, including veterinary pharmacies, may operate on Saturdays, Sundays, and public holidays, while only groceries (except alcohol and cigarettes), hygiene products and fuel may be sold in shops. On weekdays, everyone works with the same quadrature constraints. On Saturdays, Sundays and public holidays, sales points may not be open, except - pharmacies (including veterinary) and shops selling food (except alcohol and cigarettes), hygiene products, fuel. Subject to epidemiological safety measures, beauty care providers - hairdressing and manicure service providers - may operate. Libraries are allowed on site to loan out books and, subject to epidemiological security measures, museums are still available to visitors.
No change to previous policy (running until 11th January)

On 1 December 2020, the Cabinet of Ministers extended the emergency situation introducing stricter safety measures and restriction until January 11, 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201207030317/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/emergency-situation-has-been-extended-until-11-january-introducing-stricter-safety  As of 3 December, principle 2 + 2 shall be observed by everyone in Latvia in their daily routine - two meters, two people. So, a distance of two meters must be observed and meetings must be limited to two people. Until 11 January, operation of all cultural sites, exhibitions, as well as fairs, including Christmas markets, shall be prohibited. In the meantime, no more than 20% of the maximum number of people may be present at the same time in places of religious activity.  Organized meetings, pickets and marches are still allowed, but a maximum of 25 people is allowed to attend, subject to epidemiological safety requirements.

On 1 December 2020, the Cabinet of Ministers extended the emergency situation introducing stricter safety measures and restriction until January 11, 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201207030317/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/emergency-situation-has-been-extended-until-11-january-introducing-stricter-safety  On 1 December 2020, the Cabinet of Ministers extended the emergency situation introducing stricter safety measures and restriction until January 11, 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201207030317/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/emergency-situation-has-been-extended-until-11-january-introducing-stricter-safety    As of 3 December, principle 2 + 2 shall be observed by everyone in Latvia in their daily routine - two meters, two people. It is allowed to visit people who live alone and need care, observing the 2 + 2 principle. No change to previous entry:    "Currently, the actions that people are required to take after returning from abroad depend on the morbidity rates in the country where they have been: if in the last 14 days one has been in an EU, EEA, or a separate country with a 14-day cumulative number of Covid-19 cases that exceeds 50 people per 100,000 inhabitants (see list here) or if one has spent time in a third country, one must observe self-isolation. If one is returning to Latvia from the EU, EEA, or a separate country where the above-mentioned indicator does not exceed 50 people, one is not required to observe self-isolation. However, if one transits through any “unsafe countries” on the route back from a “safe” country, then self-isolation must be observed; in order to avoid the need to observe self-isolation, one must choose a safer return route"    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113091405/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/careful-travel/persons-who-wish-arrive-latvia  https://web.archive.org/save/https://covid19.gov.lv/index.php/en/support-society/careful-travel/after-arrival-latvia

It is allowed to enter Latvia, provided that the guidelines developed by the Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (SPKC) are being followed. When arriving from countries with a 14-day cumulative number of COVID-19 cases that is higher than 50 per 100,000 inhabitants, self-isolation must be observed for 10 days.  10-day self-isolation must be observed when entering Latvia from the countries listed in the “National COVID-19 morbidity rates” section of the SPKC website.  If a person is arriving from a “safe” country by transiting through an “unsafe country”, the person must observe self-isolation; in order to avoid self-isolation, a different return route must be chosen.  Self-isolation means staying in the place of self-isolation without exposing other persons to the risk of infection and without making direct contact with others (not receiving guests, not visiting anyone, not going to work or public places where many people may be present, except for going to the shop or getting to the place of residence or of self-isolation immediately after arriving in Latvia, using a mouth and nose covering).  https://web.archive.org/web/20201207042737/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/covid-19-frequently-asked-questions-and-answers
No change to previous policy.

Downtime allowance and allowance for employee salary subsidies will be available to entrepreneurs in all sectors. The support will be available for the period from 9 November 2020 to 31 December 2020. The Cabinet of Ministers on Nov 24th, has decided that the above-mentioned types of aid will be available to taxpayers affected by the Covid-19 restrictive measures in all sectors.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201207043641/https://www.mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/vitenbergs-downtime-allowance-and-allowance-employee-salary-subsidies-will-be-available

No changes to the policy (ends on Dec31st).   On November 3rd the government decided to introduce downtime allowance of around 70% of the monthly pay for workers affected by Covid-19 (the difference with spring is that any company (in all economic sectors) can now apply for the allowance if it’s fall in revenue exceeds 20%). Allowance is paid to a merchant in the amount of 70% of the merchant’s declared average salary for three months (August, September, October). The subsidy will be paid to the employee (employed, self-employed, and patent payers). The minimum amount of the subsidy is planned to be EUR 330 (the amount is determined in accordance with the net minimum wage in the country); it is planned to pay another EUR 50 for each dependent; the maximum amount of the subsidy is EUR 1000 (net). At the same time, it is stipulated that the aid paid to employees must not exceed 80% of gross salary.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201207043641/https://www.mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/vitenbergs-downtime-allowance-and-allowance-employee-salary-subsidies-will-be-available

The following things are established, in order to boost the measures of prevention and control of the COVID-19 infection in the general secondary education institutions and the early education ones:    1.1. Carrying out of online classes at the education disciplines, according to the framework plan for the forms of the primary school, gymnasium and lyceum on the period 21-24 December 2020.    1.2. Suspension, starting from 14 December 2020, of the extracurricular activities (sports circles and sections) at the headquarters of the education institutions and their carrying out online.  1.3. The education activities on the occasion of the winter holidays in schools and kindergartens will be organized in classes/groups with the observance of the social distance, with the presence of only teachers/educators from the concerned class/group. The classes and groups will be provided with proper conditions for the hygiene/disinfection of hands.     1.4. The education institution’s employees, as well as the pupils of the gymnasium and lyceum classes will compulsorily wear protection masks.       https://web.archive.org/web/20201213215125/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2020/12/11/20009882

The National Extraordinary Public Health Commission (CNESP) has ruled to establish emergency state in the public health sector all over Moldova on the period 30 November 2020 – 15 January 2021:  Ban the activity of night clubs (disco clubs, karaoke, disco pubs), starting from 28 November. At the same time, as of 30 November, the restaurants, pubs and coffee houses will be able to work till 22:00. The public nourishment units will be banned from working in the time interval 22:00-7:00.    The organization and holding of scientific conferences, sports competitions, Olympiads with the physical presence of people will be prohibited. Also, the presence of audience in theatres, movie theatres, concert halls and community centres will not be allowed.    At the same time, the public and private institutions will establish a special regime of work, with only the strictly necessary staff attracted to the working place, in order to ensure the enterprises’ functionality. The distance work will have to be organized for the personnel, whose activity does not need the compulsory presence at the working place.        https://web.archive.org/web/20201205215306/https://gov.md/en/content/national-extraordinary-public-health-commission-declares-state-emergency-public-health-all   https://web.archive.org/web/20201205214717/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

No new changes. The National Extraordinary Public Health Commission (CNESP) emergency state in the public health sector all over Moldova continues through the period 30 November 2020 – 15 January 2021.

On 8 December, additional restrictions on hours of some types of businesses were implemented:  The National Extraordinary Public Health Commission (CNESP) has ruled that, starting from today, the activity of servicing in all public nourishment units, including at those placed at the points for the sale of oil products, in commercial centres, airports, international ports, should be ceased at night, namely in the time interval 22:00-7:00.  Also, the (CNESP) members established that the public authorities subordinated to the government should work according to a special working regime, in the conditions of the pandemic situation in Moldova. Thus, the public sector employees will start their working day at 7:30 and will end it at 16:00, with a 30- minutes dinner break. The provision enters into force starting from 8 December and will be revised depending on the epidemiological situation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201213221108/https://gov.md/en/content/moldovas-national-extraordinary-public-health-commission-rules-ban-service-public

A comprehensive fiscal package has been adopted as per two 2020 State Budget Amendments, following several targeted fiscal measures to support businesses and vulnerable households, such as expanding unemployment benefits and strengthening existing targeted social assistance, tax relief for sectors affected by state-imposed restrictions, delaying tax payment deadlines to mid-2020, suspending tax audits and other controls, and increasing state budget allocations to the budget emergency and health funds and to a mortgage guarantee program.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201125052550/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Moldova joined COVAX in August 2020 and therefore, once vaccines are available it is expected that the following policy will be in place:  Thus, based on the fact that the Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunizations, through the COVAX platform ensures coverage of 20% of the country's population free of charge, the following target groups have been identified: medical workers; adults over 65 years of age and comorbidities (high risk group); beneficiaries of temporary or long-term placement centers; people with comorbidities; social workers; workers in the field of education and those in security bodies.  Subsequently, depending on the availability of the vaccine, other groups of the population will be vaccinated, which are equally extremely important.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201213220911/https://www.gavi.org/sites/default/files/covid/pr/COVAX_CA_COIP_List_COVAX_PR_24-11.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20201213221805/https://en.publika.md/moldova-made-a-request-to-covax-platform-for-covid-19-vaccine--_2662393.html

"Primary and secondary schools remain open. Students in secondary and higher education institutions must wear a face mask when not in class.  Children must stay home if they have symptoms or if someone in their household is waiting for a COVID-19 test result or if someone tests positive for COVID-19.  Colleges and universities should host virtual orientation sessions."  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://nl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-3/

"Everyone is advised to work from home unless it is not possible to complete their duties from home. Workplaces may be closed for 14 days if a COVID infection occurs."  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://nl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-3/
Current partial lockdown measures remain in place   https://web.archive.org/web/20201121205231/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/11/17/partial-lockdown-to-continue

Most events are prohibited, but the following events may take place: food markets, trade fairs and conferences, cinemas and theaters, paid football, and demonstrations.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201130214530/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/onderwerpen/coronavirus-covid-19/vraag-en-antwoord/persconferentie-coronavirus-17-november-in-eenvoudige-taal

"A maximum of 3 guests are permitted in private residences in both indoor and outdoor areas per day. This is in addition to the members of the household.  Guests should also be asked whether they have any symptoms and if they do, should not be received.  Guests should maintain 1.5-meter distance from each other."  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://nl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-3/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201130214530/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/onderwerpen/coronavirus-covid-19/vraag-en-antwoord/persconferentie-coronavirus-17-november-in-eenvoudige-taal

On all other types of transport (such as canal/river boats) passengers must maintain 1.5-meter distance."    https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://nl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-3/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201130214530/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/onderwerpen/coronavirus-covid-19/vraag-en-antwoord/persconferentie-coronavirus-17-november-in-eenvoudige-taal

Authorities in Poland have decided to prolong the ban on international flights previously imposed on nine countries, until December 31, 2020, due to the Coronavirus situation in their territories. "Lisbon, Nov. 9, 2020 (Lusa) Portugal on Monday entered a state of emergency to last until 23 November as part of the effort to combat the Covid-19 pandemic, with the imposition among other measures of an overnight curfew in 121 municipalities deemed to be most at risk in terms of new infections. The curfew, under which residents must on weekdays be off the streets from 11 p.m. to 5 a.m. and on the next two weekends from 1 p.m. to 5 a.m., is in force in municipalities that together have 70% of Portugal's population, including all those in the Lisbon and Porto Metropolitan Areas."  "Special measures were adopted in 114 municipalities considered to be at high risk, until 23 November, increasing to 191 municipalities 0 a.m. on 16 November: (...) - Closing of shops until 10 p.m.; - Restaurants with groups limited to 6 people and running until 10.30 p.m.; - Restaurant establishments exclusive to home delivery services may close until 1 a.m.  (...) Bars and Nightclubs: They remain closed and may operate only as cafes or pastries and are subject to the rules specified for these establishments."  Note: These measures are only in place in mainland Portugal hence the T flag.  Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123150158/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/node/421175%C2%A0 https://archive.vn/PI5M8

"Portugal on Monday entered a state of emergency to last until 23 November as part of the effort to combat the Covid-19 pandemic, with the imposition among other measures of an overnight curfew in 121 municipalities deemed to be most at risk in terms of new infections.    The curfew, under which residents must on weekdays be off the streets from 11 p.m. to 5 a.m. and on the next two weekends from 1 p.m. to 5 a.m., is in force in municipalities that together have 70% of Portugal's population, including all those in the Lisbon and Porto Metropolitan Areas."    During the weekends only some essential services are allowed to remain open after 1pm, including (but not limited to) pharmacies, restaurants (only takeaway), clinics and grocery stores.    Note: These measures are in place only in some municipalities in mainland Portugal hence the T flag. Subject to the restrictions in your municipality and the rules on social distancing, hand hygiene and the use of face coverings, most shops and services, restaurants, cultural venues and sports facilities are open. Opening and closing times may vary between municipalities.    As required by the State of Emergency, shops closed at 1 pm in the counties where there is a greater risk of transmission of the new coronavirus. There are already 127 municipalities in this situation.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201205224640/https://www.rtp.pt/noticias/pais/comercio-encerrado-a-tarde-em-127-municipios_v1279061    Teleworking is mandatory in all high, very high and extreme risk counties, whenever the functions in question permit and the worker has conditions to perform them, without the need for a written agreement between employer and worker.  Who does the telework obligation apply to?  - Companies that work in the municipalities mentioned above; and  - To workers, regardless of employment, who reside or work in any of the municipalities mentioned above.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201205224830/https://covid19estamoson.gov.pt/regimes-de-teletrabalho/

"Extremely high risk" and "very high risk" counties:  - On business days, commercial establishments must close until 22:00. Restaurants, cultural facilities and sports facilities must close until 22:30 (catering establishments can operate until 01:00, but only for home deliveries).  - On weekends and holidays, commercial establishments can only operate between 08:00 and 13:00. - - The catering can work after that time, but only for 'take-away' and home deliveries.    "High risk" counties:  - Commercial establishments must close until 22:00. Restaurants, cultural facilities and sports facilities must close until 22:30 (catering establishments can operate until 01:00, but only for home deliveries).    "Moderate risk" counties  - Commercial establishments cannot open before 10:00 am, with the exception of hairdressers, barbers, beauty salons, restaurants and the like, cafeterias, tea houses and the like, driving schools and technical vehicle inspection centers, as well as gyms and gyms.  - Most commercial establishments are closed between 8 pm and 11 pm, and the closing time, within this interval, as well as the opening time, may be fixed by the mayors of the city councils, subject to a favorable opinion from the local health authority. and security forces.  - Restaurants have to close at 1:00 am (with new admissions until midnight), with their capacity limited to 50% of capacity. Groups are limited to six people (unless they belong to the same household), except in establishments located within 300 meters of a school and in the food courts of shopping centers, where they are limited to four people (if not from household).

-All counties:  Prohibition of movement between municipalities in the following periods:  Between 11 pm on 27 November and 5 am on 2 December;  Between 11 pm on December 4 and 5 am on December 9;  -High-risk counties (> 240 cases):  Prohibition of circulation on public roads between 11 pm and 5 am;  Closing of commercial establishments at 10 pm;  Closure of restaurants and cultural facilities at 10:30 pm.  -Very high and extremely high risk counties (> 480 cases):  Prohibition of circulation on public roads between 11 pm and 5 am on weekdays;  Prohibition of circulation on public roads and closure of commercial establishments between 1 pm and 5 am on the following days:  Saturdays, Sundays and holidays (from December 1 and December 8):  Holiday Eve (November 30 and December 7): closure of commercial establishments from 3 pm. For municipalities with a “ high ” risk level , in addition to the measures applied to the entire continental territory:  - Prohibition of circulation on public roads between 11 pm and 5 am;  - Action to monitor compliance with mandatory teleworking ;  Maintenance of the establishment's opening hours (10 pm, except restaurants and cultural facilities at 10:30 pm).    For “ very high ” and “ extremely high ” municipalities , in addition to the measures applied to the entire national territory, the following also apply:  - Prohibition of circulation on public roads between 11 pm and 5 am on weekdays ;  - Prohibition of circulation on public roads on Saturdays and Sundays between 1 pm and 5 am;  - Prohibition of circulation on public roads on December 1 and 8 between 1 pm and 5 am;    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201213002105/https://covid19estamoson.gov.pt/renovacao-do-estado-de-emergencia/

The Government of Portugal currently prohibits non-essential (tourist) travel for U.S. citizens traveling directly to Portugal from the United States. According to Portuguese authorities, only citizens of the European Union/Schengen associated countries, their family members, or foreign nationals legally residing in a Member State of the European Union, and travelers from third-countries specifically authorized may enter Portugal    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201205203200/https://pt.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201205204251/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/eu-list-of-epidemiologically-safe-countries-amid-covid-19/

Authorities in Portugal permit entry for travelers from the EU and Schengen Area countries, the UK, Australia, Canada, China, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, and Uruguay; these arrivals do not require a COVID-19 test unless their final destination is the Azores or Madeira. Travel from other countries remains prohibited, except for limited essential reasons, including EU citizens and residents returning home, reuniting with family, and commuting to essential work or study. All such arrivals are required to submit a negative result from a COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours before boarding; however, Portuguese nationals and residents may arrange to take the test on arrival at their own expense.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201213000026/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/409031/portugal-authorities-extend-state-of-emergency-through-dec-23-amid-ongoing-covid-19-activity-update-22

The 2021 state budget adopted on November 26 foresees further support to the national health system, employment and incomes of households and firms. Key measures include:   (i) income support measures, such as temporary reduction of PIT withholdings (0.1 percent of GDP);   (ii) expanded subsidy for employment and resumption of activity (0.5 percent of GDP) and extended support for workers' lost income and coverage for those without access to unemployment protection (0.2 percent of GDP);   (iii) staff reinforcement in the civil service, particularly in health and education (0.1 percent of GDP) and an extraordinary risk subsidy in the amount of 20 percent of base salary for health professionals at the forefront of the response to COVID-19; and   (iv) VAT tax rebate to stimulate consumption in the catering sectors, accommodation and culture by returning the VAT paid on consumption in these sectors (0.1 percent GDP).

The Government presented yesterday, December 3, the Vaccination Plan against Covid-19. According to the document, the vaccine, which should arrive in Portugal as early as January, will be universal, free and optional, and will be made available to the population according to the characteristics approved by the European Medicines Agency. Three phases are planned for the implementation of the vaccination plan against Covid-19 in 2021, which will accompany the pace of availability of vaccines.    1st phase - It is intended for people over 50 with associated pathologies; residents and professionals in nursing homes and long-term care units; Health professionals; armed forces, security forces and critical services professionals. At this stage, approximately 950 thousand people should be vaccinated.    2nd phase - In this phase 1.8 million people over 65 years of age and around 900 thousand with associated pathologies and over 50 years will be vaccinated.    3rd phase - The rest of the population. The groups in this phase will be reviewed according to the pace of delivery of the vaccines    Vaccine administration  The first phase of vaccination will be administered at the approximately 1,200 vaccination points that are usual in health centers, in homes and long-term care units.  The health centers will be destined to 400 thousand people over 50 years old and associated comorbidities, while users and home professionals will be vaccinated there by the resident nursing teams.  The vaccine will also be administered to health professionals and essential services in the field of occupational medicine.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201213003729/https://www.sns.gov.pt/noticias/2020/12/04/plano-de-vacinacao-contra-a-covid-19/

According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, it is in place the obligation to wear a protective mask, to cover the nose and mouth, for all persons who have reached the age of 5, in all open and closed public spaces. Also, to avoid the congestion of public transport, it is proposed to all public institutions and all economic operators to organize work schedule (where telework is not possible) into at least two groups to start/finish the activity at a difference of at least two hours. The Ministry of Interior published the list of quarantined localities. Also, the Ministry of Health published the recommendations for preventing the spread of coronavirus (working from home where it is possible, people should avoid crowded areas and limit to the maximum any direct contact with other people, other than those who are part of the same family). Also, according to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, in all localities in Romania, it is in place a ban for traffic persons outside the home between 23:00 and 5:00 (exception for travel in professional interest, for medical assistance).  Link: https://archive.fo/cUlEp, https://s.iw.ro/gateway/g/ZmlsZVNvdXJjZT1odHRwJTNBJTJGJTJG/c3RvcmFnZTA2dHJhbnNjb2Rlci5yY3Mt/cmRzLnJvJTJGc3RvcmFnZSUyRjIwMjAl/MkYxMSUyRjA2JTJGMTI0ODQ3NV8xMjQ4/NDc1X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtNTItZGlu/LTA1XzExXzIwMjAtdjE5LTEucGRmJmhh/c2g9NjkxN2E0NDIwOTQ4MGQ1NjJiYzMxZmNjYjczZjY2NjI=.pdf and https://archive.fo/1JWbz

On 26th of October, The National Committee for Emergency Situations published Decision no.50 regarding the approval of the list of countries/areas of epidemiological risk for which the quarantine measure is instituted on persons arriving in Romania from them. Also, there are screening procedures implemented at the “Henri Coanda” International Airport (three thermal scanners and a joint action plan with the Border Police and the Public Health Directorate to collect questionnaires from travelers arriving in the country and to distribute information about local measures and restrictions).    Link: https://archive.fo/QHwSB and  https://archive.fo/9KkOQ

On 20th of November, The National Committee for Emergency Situations published Decision no.55 regarding the approval of the list of countries/areas of epidemiological risk for which the quarantine measure is instituted on persons arriving in Romania from them. Also, there are screening procedures implemented at the “Henri Coanda” International Airport (three thermal scanners and a joint action plan with the Border Police and the Public Health Directorate to collect questionnaires from travelers arriving in the country and to distribute information about local measures and restrictions).    Link: https://archive.fo/9KkOQ and https://archive.fo/lIjB1

The measures introduced by GEO 30/2020 include:   1.	The criteria for sending employees into technical unemployment and minimum income ensured for freelancers working in industries where activity is reduced or interrupted due to the pandemic.  2.	The conditions for granting free paid days to parents, to supervise their children during the temporary closure of educational establishments.  3.	The online submission of the documentation needed to gain access to social benefits.  4.	The measures for ensuring continuity in the granting of return to work incentives and childcare allowance, as well as for facilitating access to medical leave and medical leave indemnities for quarantined persons.    Link: https://archive.fo/FtT0q

On 22nd of October, the government approved the application of the simplified alternative procedure for granting payment rescheduling for a maximum of 12 months. Beneficiaries of the simplified staggering facility are all taxpayers.  According to Emergency Ordinance 69/14.05.2020, the authorities have adopted fiscal measures to help taxpayers overcome the problems caused by the COVID-19 pandemic (granting bonuses, extension of the deadline for submitting the Single Declaration, tax facilities for incentives and bonuses granted by the employer from the salary fund for the period of emergency to employees whose activity involves risk of infection with SARS-CoV-2, bonuses regarding the annual building tax and the monthly building tax, cancellation of ancillary payment obligations.  Link: https://archive.fo/OJIQT and https://archive.fo/hVM21

Ministry of Health published “Recommendations on responsible social behavior in preventing the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19)” and “Recommended measures to reduce the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic”. On 29th of October, The Government of Romania announced the List of infection diseases for which the isolation of persons is established at their home. The same document establishes the basic health units in which sick people can be treated with diseases provided in the list of infectious diseases. Also, “Datelazi.ro” (Updated data) project was released pro-bon by Code for Romania in partnership with the Government of Romania through the Authority for the Digitalization of Romania, containing data and information provided by the Government of Romania.   Links: https://archive.fo/cUlEp, https://archive.fo/klswT , https://archive.fo/Vi0vG and https://archive.fo/X428Q

According to the Ministry of Health, the units that are accredited by the Ministry of Health to perform the diagnosis by RT-PCR have the obligation to provide priority diagnosis for patients in health facilities, suspects in epidemiological investigations, and people at risk, according to the methodology of the National Institute of Public Health – National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases.   Link: https://archive.fo/6K5UM

An official document regarding contact tracing and testing of contacts of COVID-19 confirmed patient was released by National Center for Surveillance and Control of Transmissible Diseases on 23rd of July 2020. On 28th of October, the Ministry of Health published updated the flow of information used in reporting SARS CoV-2 virus infection data.  According to this document, the Directorates of Public Health (DSP) have the obligation to identify and confirm, following the epidemiological investigation, direct contacts of each person tested positive.   Link: https://archive.fo/thRdi and https://archive.fo/FUhtr

The eastern Siberian republic of Buryatia became the first Russian region to impose a second coronavirus lockdown. From November 16 to November 30, 2020, restaurants, cafes, canteens, buffets, bars, eateries and other catering facilities have been suspended, except for takeaway services without citizens visiting the premises of such enterprises, as well as delivering orders. Cinemas, beauty salons, baths and saunas are also closed for two weeks.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201122203043/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2020/11/22/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-nov-22-a69117  https://web.archive.org/web/20201122211741/https://egov-buryatia.ru/press_center/news/detail.php?ID=79386

On 21st of September, the Ministry of Education, Science and Technological Development published the recommendations for the prevention of coronavirus at higher education institutions. On 16th of October, the Deputy Direction of the Institute for Public Health announced that the COVID-19 Crisis Response Team did not consider introducing a measure of ban on movement or quarantine or switching to online classes.  Link: https://archive.fo/GY9Mo and https://archive.fo/x2px8

No policy change for schools, but there is discussion beginning on whether to close some levels again.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201125020945/https://www.b92.net/eng/news/politics.php?yyyy=2020&mm=11&dd=24&nav_id=109757

The Serbian COVID-19 Crisis Response Team announced on 25 Nov the closing of high schools and 5-8th grades of primary schools. Students are to continue schooling online until the winter break, starting on 21 Dec and ending on 18 Jan 2021. Kindergartens and grades 1-4 of primary schools are to continue open.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201207201032/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/163945/high-schools-higher-grades-of-primary-schools-switch-to-online-classes.php

No new policy changes from 08 December.    On 18 December, the existing measures in place were extended until further notice.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219180525/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219180922/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/165283/new-restrictive-measures-to-depend-on-epidemiological-situation.php

Starting with 24th of August, cinemas and theater reopened with safety measures in place (not more than 500 spectators and mandatory use of masks). After 22nd of October, all establishments (including cafes, clubs, and restaurants) can operate until 11:00 PM.  Link: https://archive.fo/ES1H0 and https://archive.fo/ZK8qD

Starting with 17th of November, all services, including bars, restaurants, cafes, stores, supermarkets, shopping malls, theaters, and cinemas will be closed from 9:00 PM to 5:00 AM.   Link: https://archive.fo/Eq7VL

From 21 November to 3 December, new measures of the Serbian Government will be in force, adopted in order to prevent the spread of COVID-19 epidemic. This is in addition to the changes implemented 17 November and will now close some shops at 6PM rather than 9PM.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201125021135/https://www.b92.net/eng/news/society.php?yyyy=2020&mm=11&dd=24&nav_id=109750  https://web.archive.org/web/20201125022744/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/163819/government-passes-new-anti-coronavirus-measures.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20201125021304/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

From 21 November to 3 December, new measures of the Serbian Government will be in force, adopted in order to prevent the spread of COVID-19 epidemic. This is in addition to the changes implemented 17 November and will now close some shops at 6PM rather than 9PM.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201125021135/https://www.b92.net/eng/news/society.php?yyyy=2020&mm=11&dd=24&nav_id=109750    https://web.archive.org/web/20201125022744/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/163819/government-passes-new-anti-coronavirus-measures.php    https://web.archive.org/web/20201125021304/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

Further restrictions were introduced on 4 Dec, with a number of workplace sectors required to close on weekends (5 pm on Friday to 5 am on Monday). This includes restaurants, shopping centres, casinos, hair salons and sports facilities. All of the above are allowed to continue open between 5 am and 5 pm on weekdays. An exception is made to food delivery services, which are allowed to function 24/7.     "Grocery stores, shops, retail facilities, as well as newsagents, kiosks and the like, where, as a rule, customers do not enter the facility in order to make the purchase, can work on weekdays and weekends until 9 pm.    Pharmacies and gas stations (fuel sales) can work non-stop, every day without restrictions.    Open-air green markets will also work on weekends from 6 am. to 3 pm."    "Medical centres and laboratories can operate throughout the day, including weekends."    http://web.archive.org/web/20201207201946/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/164342/tighter-anti-coronavirus-measures-in-effect-as-of-tomorrow.php

On 04 December, State Secretary of the Ministry of Health Mirsad Djerlek stated today that mass vaccination in Serbia is expected in the first quarter of 2021, and that a certain amount of vaccines will arrive by the end of 2020.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219184423/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/164417/mass-vaccination-in-first-quarter-of-2021.php

On 18 December, Minister of Health Zoran Loncar stated today in Novi Sad that the first doses of Pfizer vaccine will arrive in Serbia on Monday or Tuesday, adding that slightly less than 5,000 doses will arrive in the first tranche and that they will be received by users of nursing homes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219183423/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/165232/first-doses-of-pfizer-vaccine-in-serbia-on-monday.php

A small change to the previous policy, whereby secondary schools and grades 5-9 of primary schools were closed while kindergartens and primary grades 1-4 were allowed to remained open. Starting on 16 Nov 2020, "pupils from a disadvantaged environment who do not have suitable conditions for remote learning are allowed to return to school and attend classes in small numbers, with no more than five pupils in the group, plus one teacher."    Source: The Slovak Spectator    http://web.archive.org/web/20201130220822/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22536069/coronavirus-in-slovakia-measures-in-place-after-november-16.html

No changes in school policy until 07 December, when primary and secondary schools will be able to re-open if they can implement rapid testing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201205231538/https://www.uvzsr.sk/docs/info/ut/ciastka_20_2020.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20201205232259/https://korona.gov.sk/

With effect from 7 December 2020, where the operating conditions so permit and if the founder so decides:  resumes school teaching in primary schools in the fifth to ninth grades, secondary schools, primary arts schools and language schools for pupils and listeners who fulfil the conditions set out in point B.1. resolutions of the Government of the Slovak Republic No. 760 of 4 December 2020 and in decree of the Public Health Office of the Slovak Republic No. 32/2020 V. v. SR ordering measures at risk of public health to prove negative results of the test for COVID-19 disease before entering the premises of schools, and restore the operation of school facilities for pupils as referred to in point 1.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214004111/https://korona.gov.sk/obnova-vyucovania-na-skolach-od-11-12-2020/

"Following the nationwide testing and curfew, the pandemic commission decided on lifting some measures that were imposed to fight the coronavirus.      As a result, cinemas, theatres and churches were open on November 16, while some sports competitions were given a green light, although without spectators. On the other hand, restaurants, hotels and also schools remain closed for now."    Source: The Slovak Spectator, an independent English-language newspaper     http://web.archive.org/web/20201130220822/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22536069/coronavirus-in-slovakia-measures-in-place-after-november-16.html

No change in policy since November’s extension of the state of emergency, restrictions are expected to continue through the end of the year.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201205232259/https://korona.gov.sk/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201205231632/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

From 11 December, the Slovak Republic will enter a lockdown additional restrictions will be in place for some sectors:  December 11, 2020: the outdoor terraces of restaurants, cafés and similar facilities will be closed. Takeaways should be preserved. Driving schools will switch to remote classes.  December 14, 2020: stricter conditions will be implemented for hotels and ski centres: every visitor older than 10 years of age will be required to show a negative rapid or PCR test result no older than 72 hours.  In hotels, it will not be possible to eat and drink in the shared spaces.  In terms of ski lifts, only one person or people from the same household will be allowed to be on one chairlift or in one cable car.  December 21, 2020: School holiday begins and shops except for essential ones (grocery stores etc.) will be closed. The shops will stay closed for three weeks in each district, i.e. at least until January 10. It is not clear yet when schools will reopen.  December 28, 2020: Regular testing in companies with more than 500 employees will begin, so that they can return to work.  No curfew or mobility restrictions will be applied during the lockdown.  The restrictions will be lifted in those areas where the epidemic situation allows it.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201214004241/https://www.uvzsr.sk/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&layout=blog&id=223&Itemid=144  https://web.archive.org/web/20201214004530/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22551152/the-central-crisis-staff-agreed-on-lockdown.html?ref=av-center

No change in policy since November’s extension of the state of emergency, restrictions are expected to continue through the end of the year.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201205232259/https://korona.gov.sk/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201205231632/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Greater restrictions at the border as Slovakia adopts the European (ECDC) methodology to deem countries risky or less risky. All EU borders are now considered red. Those arriving from red zones are required to present a negative PCR test no older than 72 hours, register with the government website and self-isolate. Exemptions are in place for cross-border workers.     Source: The Slovak Spectator     http://web.archive.org/web/20201130220822/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22536069/coronavirus-in-slovakia-measures-in-place-after-november-16.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20201128021316/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22504724/coronavirus-in-slovakia-return-from-red-countries.html

The restrictions will be lifted in those areas where the epidemic situation allows it.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201214004241/https://www.uvzsr.sk/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&layout=blog&id=223&Itemid=144  https://web.archive.org/web/20201214004530/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22551152/the-central-crisis-staff-agreed-on-lockdown.html?ref=av-center

As of 24 November, the Slovak Republic is part of “Team Europe” and has joined COVAX. Therefore, once vaccines are available it is expected that the following policy will be in place:  The Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunizations, through the COVAX platform ensures coverage of 20% of the country's population free of charge, the following target groups have been identified: medical workers; adults over 65 years of age and comorbidities (high risk group); beneficiaries of temporary or long-term placement centers; people with comorbidities; social workers; workers in the field of education and those in security bodies.  Subsequently, depending on the availability of the vaccine, other groups of the population will be vaccinated, which are equally extremely important.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201213220911/https://www.gavi.org/sites/default/files/covid/pr/COVAX_CA_COIP_List_COVAX_PR_24-11.pdf

The government of Slovenia maintains a color-coded system of entry / quarantine restrictions:  A very small number of countries are designated “green” (epidemiologically safe).  A much larger list of countries, including the United States, are designated as “red” (poor epidemiological conditions).  In some cases, regions of countries are listed as “red.”  All non-listed countries/regions of countries  are designated “orange” (aggravated epidemiological situation).   Travelers who have spent 14 days in either a “green” country or an “orange” EU country/region can enter Slovenia without quarantine.  All others must quarantine 10 days or have a negative result from a Covid test taken in the EU within the prior 48 hours.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201121172736/https://si.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change in overall policy, but a small change to one of the Public Health Agency's recommendations: when someone in the family has been tested positive, even asymptomatic pre-school and primary school children have to stay home. This recommendation only applied to older children before.

From 7 December until 6 January, high schools will be closed. On 3 December, the Public Health Agency issued a 'recommendation' to close all high schools (gymnasieskolor - ages 16-19) for a month and move all classes online. This dose not include exams which cannot be taken at a distance.     In line with the Interpretation Guide on C1, I have coded this as '2', since "if the situation is that all schools are closed ... then that would count as a full closure".    http://web.archive.org/web/20201207153005/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/contentassets/27a3b8becacc47edbfa51273b4931886/beslut-2020-12-03-rekommendation-om-delvis-stangning-och-overgang-till-fjarr-eller-distansundervisning-gymnasieskolan.pdf  http://web.archive.org/web/20201207154159/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/regler-for-forskolor-och-skolor-som-ar-oppna-stangda-eller-varit-stangda-under-coronapandemin

On 24 Nov, a new ban on public gatherings of over 8 people came into effect. This does not apply to most workplaces, but does affect some sectors to the point where they are required to close, such as amusement parks, markets and fairs. For theaters and cinemas, the official rule is that seated audiences of up to 300 are allowed as long as social distancing measures are adhered to, although the reality on the ground is much stricter as the regions have issued non-binding recommendations which extend the 8-people limit to seated audiences.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201130190632/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud    https://web.archive.org/web/20201130190831/https://www.thelocal.se/20201123/no-public-events-for-more-than-8-people-in-sweden-including-seated-events

In force from 14 December, the Public Health Agency replaced its regional advice with national regulations and general advice, in light of the upcoming Christmas holidays. This includes the recommendation to limit the number of encounters and spend time in a "small circle" and avoid being part of several different groups, in order to reduce the number of close contacts as much as possible. "The fewer, the better." A smaller circle ["mindre krets"] is "a few people, but it is not possible to say an exact number. Who and how many are included in the circle can vary based on each individual's life situation. For some it may be some close friends, for others the immediate family."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214164556/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/jul-och-andra-hogtider/

Public transport operates at reduced capacity, has reduced the number of bookable seats and recommends using a different means of transport if there are no more bookable seats available for a specific departure time.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201214165754/https://www.sj.se/sv/om/om-sj/senaste-info-coronavirus-o-tagresor.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214165848/https://www.trafikverket.se/om-oss/var-verksamhet/sa-har-jobbar-vi-med/trafikverkets-forhallningssatt-till-coronaviruset/

In force from 14 December, the Public Health Agency replaced its regional advice with national regulations and general advice, in light of the upcoming Christmas holidays. These are divided into rules and advice aimed at individuals, with an emphasis on personal responsibility, and rules and advice aimed at businesses. Re public transport, for individuals, the recommendation is to limit the use of public transport as much as possible. Public transport companies should: 1) run schedules in such a way as to reduce the risk of congestion; 2) limit the number of passengers per vehicle; 3) inform their passengers on how they can reduce the risk of spreading the virus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214164556/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/jul-och-andra-hogtider/
No change

The government continues to require many business activities to remain closed. "The Ministry of National Education reversed its decision to shut down preschools on Friday and greenlit reopening next week amid the coronavirus outbreak.    The government announced earlier this week that all schools would switch to online education after a rise in the number of COVID-19 patients. Education Minister Ziya Selçuk, however, sent a circular to local education directorates in 81 provinces on Friday to partially reverse the decision.    “As part of consultations between our ministry and relevant agencies, it was considered to be appropriate to continue in-person education for five days a week in all public and private preschools,” the statement by Selçuk said.    Unlike other schools, which will remain closed until Jan. 4, preschools will be allowed to hold in-person education, with six classes every day. Each class, or “activity hour” as it is officially called, will last for 30 minutes. Parents who do not prefer sending their children to school will have access to online educational materials for those students."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201209131052/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/education/preschools-in-turkey-exempt-from-pandemic-related-closures    "Pre-schools in Turkey will continue face-to-face education despite a recent surge in coronavirus cases, the country's Education Ministry said Friday.    In a statement, the ministry said based on their evaluations face-to-face classes can be held five days a week in all public and private kindergartens and nurseries.    “In pre-schools, face-to-face classes will be held five days a week spread over six sessions a day, and one session will be planned for 30 minutes,” the statement added.    All education and training activities in public and private schools will continue remotely from Nov. 20 to Jan. 4, the statement added."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201209131446/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/education/turkey-pre-schools-to-continue-face-to-face-education/2050410    Note: According to the codebook childcare and nurseries are not considered as educational closures (hence the 3G code)
